title: Iconic Harley-Davidson dealer Philip Peterson dies at 91
text:
Iconic Harley-Davidson dealer Philip Peterson dies at 91 
Opened his first Harley-Davidson store in Key West in 1954 
Famous for his philanthropic events, like the Key West Poker Run 
Founded two major family-run Harley dealerships in Miami Gardens and Cutler Bay Phil Peterson celebrated the 2006 opening of his Harley-Davidson Cutler Bay location with a charity gala. Peterson’s Harley-Davidson South Miami Herald file The first annual Police Memorial Ride was held in 2010 Sunday in honor of Florida Highway Patrol Trooper Patrick Ambroise, who was killed when his patrol car was struck from behind. The ride went from Phil Peterson’s Harley-Davidson in Miami Gardens to his Cutler Bay south location. LILLY ECHEVERRIA Miami Herald file Phil Peterson (front, right) got into the Santa spirit at the 26th annual North Miami Thanksgiving Day Parade in 2000. C.W. GRIFFIN Miami Herald file A 1999 Toys in the Sun Run found Phil Peterson out front on I-95, with fellow bikers and colleagues from Peterson's Harley-Davidson location in Miami Gardens. The bikers were on a charity run. Bill Andrews Miami Herald file Phil Peterson (center) is seen in this 1997 photo as the main organizer of the Key West Poker Run, along with a crowd in front of Sloppy Joe's in Key West. Bill Andrews Miami Herald file 1 of 5 Order Reprint of this Story 
One would be hard-pressed to find a greater biker icon in South Florida than Phil Peterson, who opened his first Harley-Davidson shop on Duval Street in Key West in 1954. 
Peterson grew his Harley dealerships to main locations in Cutler Bay and Miami Gardens, as well as shops that sell Harley clothing and gear at Bayside Marketplace in downtown Miami, Dolphin Mall in West Miami-Dade and the original Key West outlet. 
Peterson, born in Green Bay, Wis., on Feb. 24, 1924, died at his Miami home on Sept. 25. He was 91. Shattering stereotypes and supporting charities will be a part of his legacy. 
“There are several sides to the biking community,” said John Birk, a biking enthusiast who has written on the subject for cycling magazines. “Most people hear of the Hells Angels but the average biker who buys a Harley is a college grad who makes $85,000 a year. He always wanted the reputation of bikers to be good.” 
Peterson lived by example. 
“He was well respected in the motorcycle community,” said Birk, a friend since he bought his first Harley from Peterson in 1965. “Anybody who rides a bike…knew Phil Peterson.” 
Indeed, as Peterson’s family wrote in an obituary sent to the Miami Herald, “Phil was an icon as a Harley dealer in South Florida for the past 60 years. He did not swear and he had no tattoos. He favored a white straw hat when not in his motorcycle helmet.” 
I’ve loved motorcyles since I was a little kid. I love the freedom. 
Phil Peterson, in a 2006 Miami Herald article. 
His list of philanthropic activities proved long and diverse: 
The Phil Peterson Key West Poker Run has endured for more than 40 years and its beneficiaries include the Diabetes Research Institute at the University of Miami Miller School of Medicine and the Key West Sunrise Rotary Club. The “motorcycle Mardi Gras,” as his son Drew Peterson called the event in a 2006 Miami Herald article, featured Peterson, into his 80s, leading the way on his Harley.  ; 
He also sponsored the Toys in the Sun Run for the Joe DiMaggio Children’s Cancer Caring Center and numerous Red Cross blood donor drives. 
In 2006, when Peterson expanded his Cutler Bay showroom by moving into a former Circuit City , he marked the occasion with a black tie and blue jeans fundraiser for The Women's Alliance, an organization that provides career training for low-income women, and for Chapter 2, a used clothing store in Miami’s Overtown neighborhood. 
“I'm heavy into charities and I'm glad to see my sons and daughters-in-law following along,” Peterson told the Miami Herald in 2006. “The more people we can help, the better off everything is.” 
After a childhood spent on the cherry farms in Wisconsin, he enlisted in the Navy in 1942. He served in combat on destroyers in the Atlantic and Pacific as a machinist’s mate first class. At 14, he met the woman who would later become his wife and fellow rider of 67 years, Charlotte, in the Peterson family cherry orchard. 
The lure of cycles proved stronger than farming, however, especially as Peterson gazed longingly at free-spirited teens who rode their bikes along the dirt roads outside his childhood home. After a period of racing on the circuit, Peterson opened his dealership in Key West. The Miami Gardens branch followed in 1965. 
“I've loved motorcycles since I was a little kid,” he said in a 2006 Herald story. “I love the freedom.” 
Peterson is survived by his wife Charlotte and their six children, Josephine Robbin, David Peterson, Jan Peterson Adelson, Dan, Drew and Dirk Peterson; nine grandchildren and five step-grandchildren. 
A memorial Mass will be at 10 a.m. Friday at St. Rose of Lima Church, 415 NE 105th St., Miami Shores. A celebration of life and memorial ride is planned later in October. Visit www.petersonsharley.com .
